millsfield:images_texts:
Kweiyang
Sunday March 31st
1935
Personal
& Confidential.
As I write
this letter I am seated in the small study room
of Dr.
Robinson of the China
Inland Mission at Kweiyang•
the room is a small kerosene lamp on the corner of the desk.
Accommodations are limited, as many refugee missionaries are in town
account of Communist activities in this province,
profuse apologies for having to put me up for
the night on a cot
This room is warmed by a charcoal fire built on a large
brass tray which in
turn rests on a wooden
frame about six inches off
the floor.
The cot takes up practically
all of the west side of the
On the wall above
are two large maps, one of Kweichow
Province and the other of China with
an"Index of Christian Missions",
the maps nailed to the
wall is a card 12 x 8 inches with
inscription "Motto for the Year"
under which
is reproduced a rather
gaudy bowl of flowers
printed in colors which in several places do not
clearly -
of like the Sunday comic pictures
- below the
"HE said PEACE - and
there was a great calm."
must have
meant that slogan,
for some other year!
The north wall is filled
mostly with book shelves partly inhabited with books.
A small card is
to a shalf.
It is a pink card with blue forget-me-nots forming
surrounding a fancy
type motto strangely reminiscent of
Clarence Howard "God 10 love."
My desk is against the east wall
decorated with more maps of the Province showing the branch
missions under the supervision of this one.
To the left is a 1955
issued by the Mellon National Bank of Pittsburgh,
that another motto - this one
burned wood "They that wait upon the
Lord shall renew their strength."
The south wall consists entirely
of French doors which open out onto a little garden bravely but poorly
Tacked to the left door is another sign
"I the Lora thy God will
hold thy right hand saying unto thee FEAR NOT."
In spite of this reasonind placard the wives of the mission-
aries stationed in this house and possibly the man also are being
evacuated tomorrow.
We flew over a group of Reds about 2000 strong
only 40 miles north of Kweiyang:
They have got in behind the Nation-
alists lines and have blown up bridges and stretches of road.
Reds or bandits move about with unbelievable rapidity.- groups defin-
itely located at a certain point will show up 40 miles away 24 hours
It is believed that they will attempt to take Kweiyang because
Chiang Kai-shek and his staff are here.
Several days ago the Reds
drew Chiang's troops away from Kweiyang retreating northward - then the
Reds made a quick reversment,
surprised a small force, crossed a river
which they were not supposed to be able to cross and
now are between
Chiang Kai-shek and the
main body of his army.
It's highly improbable
that the Reds will take Kweiyang but I am just as well satisfied to be
leaving in the morning:
We arrived at Kweiyang airport early this
afternoon - it is 20 miles south of the city
- but all of the few
automobiles and busses have been commandeered by the military and we
had to wait several hours for a
It was a Chevrolet chassis on
which a Chinese "custom built" body had been attached.
The "windows"
are of wood and the seats are 8 inch boards without backs.
The tires
are hard and the springs long since
collapsed.
Never have I taken
In Szechuen
such a beating.
near Chungking and in Chengtu all poppies - at least near roads - have
been ploughed under - but in Kweichow along the road from the airport
fields of poppies - the white blossoms just coming into bud - were
everywhere.
It is a wretched country.
They say that 95% of the
smoke opium.
The country is poor and the people poorer.
Along the road we saw many of the big-turbaned men and the quilted-skirt
women of the Miao - aboriginal tribes which existed before the coming
of the Chinese.
They have maintained their language and customs
through thousands of years.
Arriving Kweiyang we had to get out of
the bus (which was no hardship) at the gate to the city.

-2-
Xi had been commandeered to carry troops to the Red front to the
north over which we had just flown.
The city was astir with much
activity.
Kweiyang soldiers remaining behind are
boys of fifteen
or sixteen in wretched ill-fitting tattered uniforms.
Their cartridge belts
empty and
only as a handle for the rusty bayonet at the end.
their guns old and probably useful
The difficulty
of relying on such troops is that
they will gladly join the enemy
if given half a chance.
Their brothers among the bandits or Reds
have lots of apportunities for big money through looting the shops
and houses in the cities which are
In contrast to such
privileges the loyal troops get $3.00 per month when they get paia
It was very amusing at dinner tonight.
Our party consist-
ed of Mr.
and Mrs. Robinson and Mr. and Mrs.
Butler who occupy this
mission house.
Mr. Robinson about 40 - well built - talkative.
Butler - God fearing type - about 35 - firm,
efficient determined.
Mrs. Butler around 30, rather attractive and quite feminine - looks
like she would love to buy some fine lingerie if hubby would sanction
the purchase - which he very clearly would not.
Mrs. Robinson looks
older than her husband - a firm determined face - straight mouth
turning down slightly at the corners - overcome completely by
her will,
hostility and righteous indignation.
smoking which bothered her.
We compromised with the missionaries
by not taking a drink and they in turn waived objections verbally
at least,
our smoking.
The guests were Tommy Taylor, pilot
Chiang Kai-shek's Curtiss Condor and his mechanic Gay, a drawling
They had nearly
cracked up
the day before trying to stagger
off the small field at
Chungking with a heavily overloaded plane
The ship hit a klut pile of rocks at
and luckily finaly careened crazily away just escaping a very bad
They had been working all
day repairing the damaged tail
surfaces of the plane and fixing an emergency tail skid out of scrap
iron and a short section of a log.
We feared profanity but the boys
kept conversation under
Harry Smith,
spent so much time with missionaries during the last
three years
of his meanderings
around China with Chiang that he is perfectly at
home with them.
Pilot Nelson of our ship and I completed the party.
The others in our party Ki Chun, Nieh and co-pilot Wong stayed with
the French Fathers who years ago converted Nieh to the
Catholic
The conversion was not 100% successful I fear because
Nieh's wife and number one concubine always come out to the airport
together to meet him when he returns from a trip.
A hint has come to us through Mr. Butler that our
or Chungking if weather is more favorable in that direction.
turn in now.
Wednesday - April 3rd. (Flying down the Yangsze from
Hankow to Shanghai).
On Monday April
first at Kweiyang we learned
that martial law would be declared and the city
gates closed at
We could get no transportation to the field but Harry Smith,
Taylor and Gay had a Ford roadster assigned to them and we were told
that if we started walking we could get out of town before the gates
closed and could intercept Harry's car on its way back to town.
we hired a coolie to carry our baggage and after some arguments with
soldiers got outside the
commandeered for the militar:
passing several
barricades of rocks and sand bags with machine

guns in place;
a bus came along which we hailed.
of the night before and my joy over
It was like the one
getting a ride was not entirely
unmixed with regret.
However as we left the city we could hear guns
firing to the north and speed was decidedly a consideration.
field two military planes,
At the
Douglas
two place anaxs observation type,
reported the Reds as 5000 strong and headed for Kweiyang.
They were
still 40 miles away and I think will scarcely attemt to take Kweiyang
as their chances are most remote.
However we were
just as glad to be
Neither of the military planes had any bombs but one of the
pilots who returned from a scouting trip had
machine gun fire supposedly at the Reds.
The pilot, Chinese of course,
showed us the empty magazine of his gun, but there were no matte
bullet holes in his ship and I imagine he fired from too high up to
do much damage.
Our weather reports from Yunnan-fu and Chungking were excell-
ent and we decided to try to make the first flight to
Yunnan-fu.
course was to the Southwest.
There are few check points and the
country has never been mapped as to details only approximations of
After flying about 125 miles
during which time
we came to a mountain range entirely covered by clouds.
flying at 6000 feet just under the clouds and could not find a pass
through the mountains anywhere.
We therefore had to turn back to
Kweiyang which we reached at 3:30 p.m. We had good weather reports
from Chungking and plenty of time so we did not land but carried on
to Chungking•
At Kweiyang we had received a radio from Mr.
Bond at
Shanghai that our plane was needed for carrying members of Chiang
Kai-shek's staff and bank notes and that no
space would be available
thereafter for Ki Chun or me and we therefore decided to immediately
return to Shanghai leaving the trip to Yunnan-fu for another time.
Nows we are approaching Nanking and soon we will be back
Ki Chun just said
"You are the only foreigner and I
am the
Chinese who can say that they were in the Province of
Yunnan (we did fly over the Province) and 48 hours later
Shanghai."
Probably the best previous overland record was four or
five weeks except for those
wine.
travel from Yunnan-fu to Haiphong,
Indo-China by
and thence by boat to Shanghai which trip only
takes about two weeks.
As
ever
